item.title: Jennifer J. Bussell Ph.D.
item.description: Hi all! I'm a neuroscience postdoc studying information seeking and curiosity *in mice* in Richard Axel's lab at Columbia. I'll be on the academic job market this fall(!!!). Excited to be here. #introduction

item.description: Vote like our future depends on it. Because it does. https://www.nytimes.com/2023/08/04/climate/republicans-climate-project2025.html?smid=nytcore-ios-share&referringSource=articleShare #ClimateChange

item.title: Marc W Howard
item.description:
The longest functional time constant an individual synaptically isolated neuron can have is ...
.
.
.
.
Infinity!https://www.nature.com/articles/nature01171Note that this doesn't just show that stable firing can persist indefinitely. The level of stable firing depends on the history of the inputs. It's an integrating memory with an effectively infinite time constant.Really slow time constants are not necessarily evidence for network effects.

item.title: Earl K. Miller
item.description:
Very nice work showing the role of beta rhythms in top-down control of attention.
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0896627323005068The results are consistent with work showing the role of beta in top-down control of working memory
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuron.2018.09.023
and predictive coding
https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.201486811

item.title: Today I learned
item.description:
TIL a Polish charity placed a tracker on the back of a white stork to track the birds migratory habits. It travelled to Sudan before the charity lost contact. Somebody found the tracker, removed the sim card and put it in their own phone, where they then racked up $2700 worth of phone calls.https://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-news-from-elsewhere-44645217
https://www.reddit.com/r/todayilearned/comments/15iwpy9/til_a_polish_charity_placed_a_tracker_on_the_back/

item.title: aadmaa
item.description: @Neurograce This is interesting - ty! I was just rambling on about an unmet need for an interdisciplinary academic program to help activists and campaigners focus our work more effectively - here - https://mathstodon.xyz/@aadmaa/110837801132223470I left academia before I started 20 years ago and have been a campaigner (labor) ever since. There are lots of great organizers. I do think, in addition to focused academic work, we need a more effective academic program to help bridge the gap, delivering knowledge to activists.

The thousands of tons of grains that were damaged would have been enough to feed approximately 66 million people for a day.‚Äù - #UN humanitarian coordinator for #Ukraine Denise Brown.

item.title: Eric Blair
item.description:
I will die on this hill:
We will not fix our democracy until we start doing criminal prosecutions of the wealthy again. Not just weakly using DPAs and fines
and prosecutions of corporations.Musk and the hospital execs in the news today must face threats of *jail*.No fine will ever break a billionaire‚Äî they just pay out some funds and move on. But criminal charges can take down their lifestyle and hold them truly accountable.
#musk #doj #trump #indictment

item.title: Pierre Le Merre
item.description: Interesting perspective by @dlevenstein and Michael Okun.https://physoc.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1113/JP282758

item.title: Cat Hicks
item.description: A fatal flaw in the "be really hard on yourself as the mechanism to achieve" plan is that even when you achieve you absolutely cannot believe it, because you've really overtrained being hard on yourself. You see a systematic undervaluing that robs you of true information about your work.So, one of the hallmarks of maladaptive high achievement I look for, as a psychologist studying productivity, is inability to really celebrate.

This, from @Neurograce seems a really great, practical guide for the kind of things academics can do re climate. Worth reading. Lots of great links to organisations and more as well. https://gracewlindsay.com/2023/08/04/so-youre-an-academic-who-wants-to-help-with-the-climate-crisis/#climatechange

item.title: Jim Carson / WT8P
item.description:
TIL: Charles H Turner, who *died 100 years ago* at the age of 56, pioneered experiments that to test if other creatures have capacity for solving problems. His work focused on bees, spiders, ants, and moths.
#science #charlesturner* Bees can navigate by landmark.
* Spiders adjust web building to the locale, prey optimization.
* Ants evaluate a situation and come up with a goal-oriented approach (vs trial and error) https://knowablemagazine.org/article/living-world/2023/rediscovering-legacy-charles-henry-turner

item.title: myrmepropagandist
item.description:
@albertcardona Pranking the Neighbors:
When you have a nocturnal species that lives close to a species that's active during the day. Ants generally put their garbage as far from the nest as they can manage, but if they see another ant colony's nest entrance nearby they will fill the entrance with garbage while their neighbors are asleep (husks of dead insects, old silk pupae, debris from excavation)I've observed this many times, but I do think it's in one of the documentaries too.
